qas.question: What should a conceptual data model do?

answers.text: reflects the structure of the information to be held

qas.question: What makes a successful data model?

answers.text: accurately reflect the possible state of the external world being modeled

qas.question: What must one understand in order to create a successful data model?
Asking questions about an organization's needs will help to create what?

answers.text: definitions of the terminology used for entities

plausible_answers.text: reflects the structure of the information to be held

qas.question: What does a conceptual data model never do?
What data model is no longer a popular approach?
What must one have no knowledge of in order to create a successful data model?
Who is not allowed to produce a conceptual data model?

plausible_answers.text: Designing a good conceptual data model

qas.question: What involves asking shallow questions to improve a data model?

context: The first task of <b7_0>a database designer<b7_0/> is to produce a conceptual data model that <a0_0><b4_0>reflects the structure of the information to be held<b4_0/><a0_0/> in the database. A common approach to this is to develop an entity-relationship model, often with the aid of drawing tools. Another popular approach is the <b5_0>Unified Modeling Language<b5_0/>. A successful data model will <a1_0>accurately reflect the possible state of the external world being modeled<a1_0/>: for example, if people can have more than one phone number, it will allow this information to be captured. <b8_0>Designing a good conceptual data model<b8_0/> requires a good understanding of <a2_0><b6_0>the application domain<b6_0/><a2_0/>; it typically involves asking deep questions about the things of interest to an organisation, like "can a customer also be a supplier?", or "if a product is sold with two different forms of packaging, are those the same product or different products?", or "if a plane flies from New York to Dubai via Frankfurt, is that one flight or two (or maybe even three)?". The answers to these questions establish <a3_0>definitions of the terminology used for entities<a3_0/> (customers, products, flights, flight segments) and their relationships and attributes.
